newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Mixed bag of earnings seen for NZ's Fletcher.
newsitem.headline: Mixed bag of earnings seen for NZ's Fletcher.

text.p: Fletcher Challenge, reporting for the first time as four separately listed divisions, is expected to produce a mixed bag of results when it reports next week, analysts said on Friday.
FCL Paper and FCL Building were both expected to report stronger earnings, but FCL Energy and FCL Forest were expected to show declines.
Paper's result was also likely to mask a dismal picture in its key areas of pulp and paper.
Paper's last four halves show how highly cyclical its business is. In the six months to December 1994, FCL paper earned NZ$21 million (US$14.5 million).
The result swelled to NZ$151 million in the ensuing six months and to $186 million in the third.
In contrast, analysts expect the half to June 30, 1996 to show just a few million in earnings. Some expect Paper to break even and others see a loss over the half.
"What that shows is the impact of a very short upswing in pulp and paper prices and a very rapid downswing," David Stanley at Doyle Paterson Brown said.
Furthermore, there was little to suggest an improvement in commodity prices in the year ahead.
Paper made NZ$172 million in the year to June 1995 and analysts expect a profit for 1996 of around $190 million. The range of most analysts' expectations is $175-$210 million.
Paper has underperformed the market since the energy, building and paper divisions were split from the group in March, which coincided with a sharp downturn in pulp and paper markets.

Abysmal log prices and other factors are likely to combine to drag Forest's earnings down to around NZ$65 million in the year to June against $68 million a year ago, but the market will not be too concerned.
Forest has been riding the crest of a wave after successfully bidding, along with Brierley Investments Ltd and China's Citic, for Forestry Corp of NZ on Tuesday.
The stock has been powering ahead since the sale announcement, and closed on Friday at NZ$2.03, up nine cents.
The move almost doubles Forest's estate to around 300,000 hectares.
"I don't think people care about the result because they are focusing far more on the implications of the acquisition of Forestry Corp," Stanley said.
Forest itself had been assisted by the price the consortium was prepared to pay -- NZ$2.026 billion -- in that it improves the valuation of Forest's existing estate.
Building, fresh from cost cutting measures and a move out of unprofitable businesses, is expected to produce a healthy improvement in annual earnings.
Analysts expect a result in the region of NZ$137-8 million before abnormals, up substantially from $117 million a year earlier, and are generally positive about prospects.
Energy is expected to report a decline in annual profit before abnormal items, largely due to the operation of its Maui B platform.
Energy made a NZ$32 million profit on the sale of its interest in Bay of Plenty Electricity, but the sale happened after balance date and was unlikely to be included.
Analysts expect a net profit of around NZ$45-6 million, down from $64 million last June year.

Paul Richardson, energy analyst at SBC Warburg, said earnings before interest and tax would be around NZ$120 million, but the underlying profit was going to be lower than last year's. He expects a fall to around NZ$50 million.
